messages.content: short answer is a proof is a proof of computation on top of public/private input, resulting in a public output

Regarding the guranteed exact code execution of the method as it was written, wouldn't that be enforced by the prover and verification keys? Is it possible for an attacker to alter a `@method` and still be able to generate a valid proof, if the appropriate assertions are not made?

Regarding the `.assert`() statemetns on the state of the Smart Contract, I understand that those are necessary because the value that the cliet reads from the GraphQL API may be different from the value stored on chain, and this is why this assertion is put in place, to prevent this array of attacks, since the return value of the GraphQL API provides no guarantees that it was not spoofed, or that the client didn't fake it locally. Are the `.assert*()` checks necessary if the value that the client reads from there is not important?
I believe you mean "private a&b"

in case of zkapp methods, you are proving that given the private input (args), the smart contract is issuing account updates. Then the chain can take the account updates and verify they have been issued by your @method - since it produced the proof - which attests via public input/output that it created a list of AUs
no, inputs can be both private & public, zkapp method args are private, but behind the scenes public input is used for attesting the hash of AUs issued
this is best demonstrated in the ZkProgram API

Thank you, this is very clear. However, what guarantees that the code of the method was unmodified? Is it the prover and verification keys, since they "hash" on the source code of the method (or rather the resulting circuit?).
Yes, Account Updates actually become the public input to the proof, upon which the proof is constrained, but that still leaves without a full understanding of the guarantees of the code execution.

Guarantee is that once you compile the code, it produces a verification key which is stored on-chain, then once your @method provides a proof, it is verified against the verification key. there’s a lot of big boy cryptography that the proof system takes care of, which is beyond my expertise. Point is if you change the method code, you will end up generating a different proof that cant be verified by the ‘real’ verification key
proof is like a trace of execution i think, if the execution trace is different so is the proof, so the original verification key wont verify the new circuit proof

> Point is if you change the method code, you will end up generating a different proof that cant be verified by the ‘real’ verification key
If this is indeed true (which is the main point where I would like to obtain understanding on), then the source of the method/circuit if essentially hashed, and included as a commitment in the prover and verifier keys. In that case, assertions are only really needed if you want to attest to the equality to the on-chain data or the validity of data provided by the user (e.g. that they have provided a number which hashes to the value stored on-chain).
Thanks a lot for the answers @maht0rz
i think hashed is an understatement and the execution trace of the circuit is the core building block of how you arrive at the prover/verifier keys
for the assertions, there are two main kinds, the ones you may be using in a smart contract’s state api end up creating preconditions via AUs rather than failing the proof generation itself.
btw there’s the Kimchi book if you want to learn more about the proof system itself, its pretty thorough
https://o1-labs.github.io/proof-systems/specs/kimchi.html
UInt64.from(0).assertEquals(UInt64.from(1)) // this will fail proof generation

> i think hashed is an understatement and the execution trace of the circuit is the core building block of how you arrive at the prover/verifier keys
Yes, presiely. It's an observation of the computation. This is why I included "hashed" in quotes in the first message. By "Hashed" I meant comitted to/embedded, in the sense that the actual circuit/source code is an input to generating the prover and verification keys, and any alteration to the circuit would lead to the alteration of those.
Thaank you!! I will read it in detail.
WOW
How come I didn't run across the MiNA book before??
Thank you very much for the link
